entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Consolidated Error Messages in SAC Story Designer
entry.content:
An Efficiency Boost for SAC Story Designers: The New Consolidated Info Panel with the 2026.Q1 (2026.01) Release

Hello fellow SAC Story Designers,

Anyone who has already worked with the new "Model Repointing" feature knows how powerful it is. It offers enormous flexibility, but it also brings with it a challenge: after repointing a model, there is a significant risk that objects in the story will "break" - be it due to unmapped bindings, changed hierarchies, or other inconsistencies.

Previously, this meant one had to tediously navigate through every page and widget to re-establish confidence that the dashboard was in a proper, consumable state. This process was not only time-consuming but also prone to error.

For exactly this scenario, and similar ones, a decisive improvement has been introduced within the Story Design Time: the new, consolidated Info Panel. It is designed to become your central point of control for quality assurance.

The Old Way: Fragmented Information

Let us remember: Issues and recommendations were displayed in various places:

  • Critical errors (for example, a broken data binding) often appeared as individual toast messages or small icons on the widget itself.
  • Performance recommendations were somewhat hidden in a separate popup or in tooltips.

The result was a fragmented overview where one had to actively hunt for problems and could easily miss something.

The New Way: One Panel for Everything

The new Info Panel, which you can access via the icon in the top toolbar, breaks with this fragmentation. It consolidates all relevant messages in one location, giving you a clear and immediate overview of your story's health.

 

Caption: The new, consolidated Info Panel with its 'Issues', 'Performance Recommendations', and 'Scripting Errors' tabs.

Let us look at the decisive improvements in more detail:

The "Issues" Tab: The New Core Component

The most important new area is the "Issues" tab. Here, all asset-related problems are centrally collected and intelligently structured:

  • Clear Categorization: The messages can be filtered by severity (Error, Warning, Info) and are color-coded, so you see immediately what is critical.
  • Logical Structure: The list is grouped hierarchically by page and widget. You can see at a glance which chart on which page is affected.

Typical issues that you will find here are, for example:

  • Missing Input Control: A control element was deleted that is required by a chart.
  • Invalid Calculation: A calculation is no longer valid because it depends on another, missing calculation.

Integrated Performance and Scripting Insights

Next to the "Issues" tab, you find the familiar sections, which are now, however, seamlessly integrated:

  • Performance Recommendations: The proactive tips for optimizing widget performance are now also part of this central panel. Consequently, you have performance and functional issues in one view. Please check also our separate blogpost on this topic SAP Business Data Cloud - Performance Recommendations for Story Designers
  • Scripting Errors: For all who work in "Advanced Mode," scripting errors are also consolidated here, which simplifies the debugging of complex interactions considerably.

The Concrete Value for Your Daily Workflow

  • Security after Model Repointing: Instead of a manual search, you simply open the Info Panel and receive a complete list of all problems that resulted from the repointing.
  • Significant Time Savings in Debugging: The direct action links ("Open Builder Panel") reduce the click paths and search effort to a minimum.
  • Increased Story Quality: You will no longer overlook warnings or "smaller" problems and can therefore ensure a consistently high quality of your dashboards.
  • A More Efficient Workflow: All information relevant to the story's health is bundled in one place. No more jumping between different menus and views is necessary.

Conclusion

The new, consolidated Info Panel is more than just a cosmetic update. It is a fundamentally improved tool that directly addresses the pain points of us, the story designers. It proves its value especially in scenarios like Model Repointing, by helping us to quickly and reliably maintain control over complex stories.

It is a small but highly effective step towards a cleaner and more efficient design process.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Management of Classic Stories Before Deprecation
entry.content:
Targeted Management of Classic Stories Before Deprecation with the 2026.Q1 (2026.02) Release

Hello everyone,

As many of you know, a significant technical transition is on the horizon for SAP Analytics Cloud: with the Q2 2026 release, "Classic Stories" will be officially deprecated. From this point on, it will no longer be possible to open or edit stories based on the old stack. The path forward is the conversion of this content to the "Optimized Story" format.

To support you in this process, we have previously provided tools that identify which Classic Stories are still actively in use. This approach of targeted conversion has helped many of you to set priorities (you can read more about this in our blog post on Efficient Migration of SAC Classic Stories: Focusing on the Essentials).

However, based on your feedback, we are now taking this a significant step further. Instead of just focusing on stories that are in use, we're now giving you the tools to get a complete overview and proactively clean up your system.

What's New? Three Key Enhancements for Your System Management

To make the transition as smooth as possible, we have specifically enhanced three areas of SAP Analytics Cloud:

1. A Complete, Exportable List of All Classic Stories

In the System > Overview > Content area, you will now find a new, comprehensive table. This table lists all Classic Stories present in your system‚Äîregardless of whether they have been used recently or not. The key advantage: this list is fully exportable. You can easily load the data into Excel or another tool to sort, filter, and align with business departments.

2. Targeted Deletion of Classic Stories in Housekeeping

A clean system is a performant system. We have enhanced the System > Overview > Housekeeping area to allow you to specifically filter for Classic Stories and delete them directly, even in bulk. This builds upon the existing housekeeping functionalities and provides you with a powerful tool for system hygiene. (For a general introduction to this topic, you can refer to our Efficient Data Maintenance in SAP Analytics Cloud System Overview - Housekeeping.)

 

 

3. Enhanced Metadata for Custom Analyses

For those who want to perform deeper analyses or build their own monitoring dashboards, we have enhanced the underlying data model, known as the 'Resource' model. This model is part of the standard monitoring content that is automatically updated with every system update. You can find this content under the path Files > System > Common > SAC Content.

Our recommendation is to use the standard dashboards provided there to track the progress of your migration efforts.

However, if you wish to build your own analyses or tables to specifically list Classic Stories, you can do so directly on the 'Resource' data model. To get a precise list, apply the following filters to the data source:

  • Resource Version: CLASSIC
  • Object Type: STORY
  • Resource Subtype: (No Value)

 

These filters ensure that you are exclusively looking at Classic Stories and not other object types or subtypes, such as bookmarks, in your analysis.

A Recommended Workflow

  1. Inventory: Export the complete list of Classic Stories from the System > Overview > Content area.
  2. Analysis & Decision: Go through the list and classify each story: Convert or Delete?
  3. Execution:
    1. Convert the necessary stories to the Optimized Story experience.
    2. Use the new feature in Housekeeping to remove the obsolete stories.
  4. Monitoring: Keep track of your progress, either with the standard content found under Files > System > Common > SAC Content or with your own custom analysis.

Summary

The Q2 2026 deadline is set. With a complete overview, targeted deletion capabilities, and enhanced metadata, you now have full control over the process. We recommend starting to familiarize yourself with these new tools early to ensure a smooth transition and to start the future with a clean system.

entry.title: Re: Data category : Dimension vs Cube
entry.content:
Hello,

Your question is very broad, so I'll only be able to give a broad answer. 

In general, a "Fact" view is a view that contains transactional data. 
Think things like "Sales", "Orders" and so on. 
You have some columns, and you have a number:

Profit CenterMATERIALQUANTITY SOLD
1000000110
1000000220

A dimension on the other hand, are each of the column, that contain any other information: In this case, "MATERIAL" and "Profit Center" are your dimensions.

Even though you might not be working with CDS views, I think the general documentation might be helpful:

Dimension Views | SAP Help Portal
Fact Views | SAP Help Portal

So. If your view is based on a tables that contain transactions: Fact.
Each column in that fact view is potentially: Dimension.

entry.title: Re: Management of Mold Manufacturing
entry.content:
Explore the below recommended approaches

1. Project System (PS) + Investment Management
Treat the mold as an internal project (WBS element). Assign all raw materials and subcontracting services to the WBS. Use network activities to represent subcontracting stages. This way, you can track costs, materials issued, and services received against the project until capitalization. At completion, settle the WBS to an Asset Under Construction (AuC), then capitalize to the fixed asset.

2. Special Stock for Subcontractor (Stock Type O)
SAP allows you to manage customer or subcontractor stock separately. You can issue raw materials to subcontractor stock (movement type 541) and track them until the mold returns. This gives you visibility of inventory physically at the subcontractor site without creating new material codes.

3. Combination: PS + Subcontractor Stock
Use PS/WBS for overall mold investment tracking. Use subcontractor stock for material visibility. Costs of subcontracting services are posted to the WBS, while materials are tracked in stock type O. When the mold is received, you settle the WBS to the fixed asset.

4. Avoiding Excess Material Masters
Instead of creating a new material code for each mold, treat the mold as a project/asset, not a material. Only maintain material masters for raw materials and standard components. The mold itself is created directly as an asset master record once complete.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on SLD Parameters for Managed System Se...
entry.content:
Hello team,

Refer to below documentation:

2729787 - FAQ: SAP HANA Data Supplier for System Landscape Directory (SLD), Solution Manager and Focused Run (FRUN)

B) You have no HSR scenario configured:

You configured on your HANA system:

nameserver.ini
[SLD]
enable_virtdbhome = true

but you did not configure the depending parameters in

global.ini
[system_landscape_hostname_virtualization]
#sldvirtdbhome    =
#sldsystemhome  =

To solve the issue, disable the parameter for virtual host name usage

nameserver.ini
[SLD]
enable_virtdbhome = false

 

Configuring an SAP HANA System to Connect to the System Landscape Directory (SLD)

______________________________________________________________________________ 

Thanks and best regards,
Luis Salazar
SAP Technical Support - ALM
______________________________________________________________________________

entry.title: Re: Person ID to User ID Synchronisation to be Avoided du...
entry.content:
Hi bbknrt,

The User ID is the system‚Äôs unique identifier for an employment record and, for EC customers, it is hardcoded mapped to the Personal ID External at the time of initial hire.

In cases of multiple employments, such as when a Concurrent Employment or Global Assignment is added, the system automatically generates the User ID for this second employment, while the Personal ID External remains unchanged. This User ID is generated based on the ‚ÄúNext Person ID Assigned‚Äù value configured in Company, System and Logo Settings.

In summary, it is not possible to define a different User ID for EC new hires, as the User ID is hardcoded mapped to the Personal ID External.

I hope this helps!

Thank you.

Best Regards,

Karen Perez

entry.title: Re: Changeable and not changeable item category in a sale...
entry.content:
You have not explained the issue clearly neither shared the screen shots without which, it will be difficult to assist you. Please answer the following:

  1. Are all three line items created with the same item category (TAN), or is there any difference in customizing or determination?
  2. Has an outbound delivery been created only for the first line item, or was there any partial delivery attempt for the second or third?
  3. You mention the second and third items are ‚Äúnot confirmed.‚Äù Do they have confirmed quantities in ATP or are they completely unconfirmed?
  4. Is the item category TAN set up in customizing to allow changes to TAB, and is this setting identical for all three items?
  5. You note delivery priority is editable for both items. Is this field editable because no delivery exists yet, or is there a difference in schedule line status?
  6. For the third line item, is the item category field greyed out, or does it throw an error when you attempt to change it?
  7. Are there any differences in material master, schedule line category, or requirements class between the second and third items?

entry.title: Re: How to call AS ABAP from SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hi, @albertosimeoni 

Unfortunately, you are correct: my idea is about how to trigger ABAP code execution, but not about how to transfer data from Datasphere to AS ABAP.üôÅ    Inability to use parameters is a severe restriction.    

Your second question "the source to be extracted is the output of an ABAP report" is slightly simpler. This is exactly my case. I have an ABAP report that filling a custom Z-table with calculation results. I created two flows.

First data flow is OData-based, as I described in blog. And I use "SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN" in my CALCULATE method.

Then I created a replication flow, based on usual connection of type 'SAP S/4HANA On-Premise'. This flow simply a load of data from Z-table  into Datasphere.

Finally, I made a task chain from these two flows. When chain run starting, first flow triggering my program and waiting for calculation finish (due to 'AND RETURN' addition. When program results ready and written to Z-table, first flow finis and task chain call second flow to replicate prepared data into Datasphere.

entry.title: Re: How do I maintain a warranty period for a material as...
entry.content:
Below are the recommended solution

  • Maintain warranty templates in customizing with validity periods (e.g., 12 months, 24 months).
  • Assign templates to materials (or material groups) so they are automatically inherited when equipment is created.
  • Use sales org/market logic to differentiate warranty templates if periods vary by region.
  • Ensure the start date is set automatically from delivery or installation, so users don‚Äôt need to enter it manually.

entry.title: Re: Cost Center changes for employee and active Customer...
entry.content:
When an employee switches cost centers within the same company code, the impact depends on how the project is set up and how costs are captured:

What happens in standard SAP is existing postings (time confirmations, expenses, activity allocations) remain with the old cost center. They are historical records and are not automatically re‚Äëassigned. Future postings (after the organizational change) will flow to the new cost center once the employee‚Äôs master data (HR assignment or activity type allocation) is updated. The project itself doesn‚Äôt automatically update to reflect the new cost center; it continues to show the old one for past postings.

The Best Practice is

  • Keep history intact (don‚Äôt change past postings).
  • Update project master data for responsibility and future postings.
  • Only repost costs if reporting or controlling requirements demand it.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q4 2025: Release Highlights
entry.content:
In Q4, we rolled out AI-powered enhancements for SAP UI5 development, digital experiences, and SAP Mobile Start, along with improved operational control and visibility for automating business processes. Most significantly, the agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available, empowering developers to build custom Joule agents.

Check out our Top 10 Q4 2025 Release Highlights!

 

Enhancements and AI-Powered Development

AI-guided development for building agents in Joule Studio.

 1. Building custom agents with Joule Studio

Now generally available, the agent builder in Joule Studio lets developers create custom Joule agents using natural language, Model Context Protocol (MCP) enabled integrations, multi-agent orchestration, and existing SAP Build content. With this capability, you can build scalable, production-grade agents designed to deliver real business impact across your enterprise.
Learn more in this blog post.

 

2. AI-powered capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

Joule is now integrated across all SAP Build Work Zone editions, helping employees navigate complex workflows within their digital workspace using natural language queries. With context-aware answers, content generation, and proactive insights, Joule helps teams work more productively.
Learn more in this blog post.

 

3. Enhanced AI support for SAPUI5 development

With the new /ui5-create-app slash command in Joule for SAP Build Code, developers can now generate freestyle UI5 applications. The AI assistant/Joule guides the conversation, producing a ready-to-use, best-practice app as a starting point. This streamlines development, reduces setup effort, and helps teams follow consistent UI5 standards from the very beginning.
Learn more in this blog post.

How the AI-supported freestyle SAPUI5 app generation works. Learn more in this blog post.

 

4. Define status flows in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP)

The new status flow feature in CAP lets developers define application workflows with minimal effort using just three CDS annotations. With @flow.status, @from, and @TO, developers can mark status properties and define transitions, while the system automatically generates the necessary handlers and UI annotations. This reduces manual coding, provides a robust framework, and still allows developers complete control to override and customize the generated logic.
Learn more in the guide.

 

 

Enhanced Operational Control and Automation

5. Streamline migration to SAP Build Process Automation

With the ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature in Process Visibility, organizations can smoothly transition from SAP Workflow Management to SAP Build Process Automation. This feature enables tracking of legacy and new processes in a single, unified view without data duplication or reporting disruptions, helping organizations modernize their operations while maintaining visibility, accuracy, and performance.
Learn more in this blog post.

 

6. Expanded functionality for process automation

  • Template-based notifications: You can now compose template-based notifications using HTML as part of your process logic, enabling teams to design more flexible e-mails that fit complex business scenarios.

    Learn more.
  • Preserve and combine results for Decision Tables: Decision Tables in process automation now support aggregating and preserving outputs from multiple tables. With the new append operation, users can accumulate results across multiple rule evaluations, enabling richer decision outcomes.  
    Learn more    .

    When opening an existing decision that uses list-type results, users will see a banner notification indicating that the behaviour has changed.

    If the user clicks on ‚ÄúUpdate Decision Table Behavior‚Äù, the user gets to select to continue with the existing behavior or choose the new behavior to append the content to the result.
  • Enable or disable individual Decision rules: While modeling decisions in process automation, you can now activate or deactivate individual rules based on business requirements. The deactivated rules are skipped during execution but remain accessible, providing greater control of Decision artifacts.

    Learn more.
  • Manage workflow tasks in process automation: Workflow monitoring applications now support assigning tasks to a group, improving flexibility and reducing manual effort. Administrators can search for users or groups, reassign running workflow instances, and receive clear confirmation or error messages, ensuring business continuity.

    Learn more.

 

7. Expanded trigger options for SAP Build Process Automation

SAP Build Process Automation now offers enhanced trigger options that enable scalable automation across SAP and non-SAP systems:

  • Queue triggers to start a process: These triggers leverage UiPath Queue Management to start SAP Build Process Automation processes automatically, enabling the smooth automation of repetitive tasks. Learn more.
  • UiPath connector triggers: These event-driven triggers powered by UiPath Integration Service enable automation across non-SAP systems, providing real-time responsiveness to critical business activities with minimal configuration effort. Learn more.

 

Digital Experience & Mobile Start Innovations

8. Enhanced user experience for mobile and desktop in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition

SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition now provides a coherent and intuitive navigation model across desktop browsers and SAP Mobile Start. Employees can quickly access the apps and business content they need on the go through structured spaces and pages. By organizing content into logical workspaces, essential tools open in seconds, reducing operational friction, minimizing errors, and enabling users to stay productive while moving between tasks.
Learn more in the Help Portal.

 

9. Updates to SAP Mobile Start

SAP Mobile Start adopts Apple's new Liquid Glass design language released with iOS 26.

SAP Mobile Start continues to elevate the mobile experience for end-users with several new features that improve usability, efficiency, and visual design:

  • Adoption of Apple‚Äôs Liquid Glass design: SAP Mobile Start now incorporates Apple‚Äôs new Liquid Glass design language introduced with iOS 16. This provides a more dynamic user experience and increases screen space as the navigation bar collapses when not needed.
  • Additional To-Do filter option ‚ÄúGroup‚Äù: End-users can now filter their To-Dos by semantic groups defined in Task Center, making it easier to organize and prioritize tasks.
  • New compact list view for To-Dos: To-Dos can now be displayed in a more compact list view instead of the traditional cards view, allowing users to see more items at a glance and manage tasks more efficiently.

Learn more in the latest blog post.

 

10. Expanded content capacity in SAP Build Work Zone sites

SAP Build Work Zone sites can now host thousands of documents and translations without technical limits. This lets administrators build richer site architecture that supports multiple regions and languages while keeping content organized, giving employees faster access to a comprehensive and well-structured digital workplace.

 

 

Ready to see these in action?

Join us for the next What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Webinar on February 5th as we explore building custom agents with Joule Studio, AI support for SAPUI5, and more!

 

Choose your session:

üïò9:00 AM - 10:00 AM CET ‚Üí https://url.sap/al5xcu

 üïì 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM CET ‚Üí https://url.sap/egqfui

entry.title: Removal of Business Groups in SAP BTP ABAP Environment: Switching to Spaces and Pages
entry.content:
Recently, we announced My Home in SAP BTP ABAP environment.
My Home is your personalized entry page that provides you with easy access to the business insights and applications you need to do your job with greater speed and agility.

As a prerequisite for My Home, SAP Fiori launchpad spaces and pages need to be enabled.
The spaces mode was developed to offer more flexibility to influence the launchpad layout for specific user groups. Pages are assigned to users via spaces that are assigned to business roles. The business role defines which users see a specific space. By defining pages with meaningful sections, you can define in which order the apps are sorted on the page.

 

Switching to Spaces and Pages

Spaces and pages have been announced as the standard layout approach for structuring content in the SAP Fiori launchpad with SAP BTP ABAP environment 2302.
Consequently, the classic Fiori launchpad home page with business groups will be removed gradually until 2608 in favor of SAP Fiori launchpad spaces and pages.

Luckily, this is no news: The transition is going on for quite some time now, as spaces and pages are already the default in newly provisioned systems for several years. 
The removal of groups will affect newly provisioned systems at first with 2602. Later, with 2605, the switch will take place for existing systems as well.

This means in detail:

  • With 2602, it is no longer possible to switch between spaces and pages and the classic Fiori launchpad home page with groups in newly provisioned systems.
  • With 2605, spaces and pages will be the default in existing systems as well. The option to switch to the classic home page with groups will still be available for end users if the administrator has enabled it in the Manage Launchpad Settings app.
  • With 2608, the option to switch to the classic FLP home page will be removed completely in production systems.

 

How to Prepare for the Transition

Good news: The transition is straightforward, but there are a few important points to note. Until now, users couldn‚Äôt create their own groups in the SAP BTP ABAP environment. They relied on SAP-delivered groups and personalized them by adding, removing, or renaming tiles.

SAP provides predefined spaces and pages with similarly structured content. SAP-delivered groups will be switched to these predefined spaces and pages. Important: user-level personalizations made to the previous groups will not be carried over and will be lost due to the switch. You will need to recreate personal adjustments after the transition.

To be as well prepared as possible, we recommend administrator to enable the switch to spaces and pages now to remain productive after the transition.

Here are our best practices for end users:

  • Plan the switch carefully and identify which adjustments are important to you.
  • Document your existing personalizations so you can rebuild them in spaces and pages.
  • Use SAP‚Äôs predefined spaces and pages as a starting point and tailor them to your workflow.

 

For Administrators: Summary of the Upcoming Changes

As part of the mentioned transition to spaces and pages, SAP will change the SAP Fiori launchpad settings in the Manage Launchpad Settings app for administrators accordingly over the next release upgrades:

With SAP BTP ABAP environment 2602:

  • The parameter SPACES is removed in newly provisioned systems.

  • The parameter SPACES_ENABLE_USER is removed in newly provisioned systems.
  • The parameter SPACES_CUSTOM_HOME is true (ON) as default for all existing and newly provisioned systems. The setting to disable My Home is still available. Since spaces and pages need to be enabled as a prerequisite for My Home, this needs to be manually activated for existing systems.

With SAP BTP ABAP environment 2605:

  • The parameter SPACES is true (ON) as default in existing systems.
  • The parameter SPACES_ENABLE_USER is false (OFF) as default in existing systems. The settings to enable switching between the classic FLP homepage and the spaces and pages layout is still available.

With SAP BTP ABAP environment 2608:

  • The parameter SPACES is removed.
  • The parameter SPACES_ENABLE_USER is removed.
  • The parameter SPACES_CUSTOM_HOME is removed.

 

Ultimately, there will be no option to switch back to groups or to enable toggling between spaces and pages and groups after the SAP BTP ABAP environment 2608 release upgrade. You must complete the transition to spaces and pages before the final, irreversible switch in production systems with the 2608 release upgrade.

We therefore invite all customers to begin transitioning now and proactively embrace this change.

entry.title: Environment, Health, and Safety in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

 SAP Cloud ERP is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the cloud ERP ecosystem‚Äìcustomers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I‚Äôd like to outline the innovations for SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Release in the area of Environment, Health, and Safety. These are the topics that are covered:

 

Cross Functions for Environment Management and Workplace Safety: 

  • Planning and execution of EHS inspections (7Z7)
  • Improved operational compliance overview page with new task insight metrics (4C8)

Workplace Safety:

  • Expansion of UK-specific incident regulatory reporting (3FP)
  • Investigation overview on the investigation object page (3FP)

 

In case you do not need all the information below and briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch this video with the top four key innovations:

 

 

Video#1: SAP Cloud ERP 2602 for Environment, Health, and Safety

 

 

Planning and execution of EHS inspections



Business Background
Organizations are required to conduct inspections to comply with numerous regulations and permits, such as those from OSHA or environmental agencies. A systematic process is essential to identify, document, and correct unsafe conditions and non-conformities, thereby preventing incidents and protecting employees and the environment.

Key Features
This new capability provides a brand-new inspection management process within EHS. It allows users to centrally create and manage checklists and execute ad-hoc inspections on-site using a mobile device. The functionality is fully integrated with foundational task management for planning and tracking corrective and preventive actions that arise from inspection findings.

 

 

Video#2: Demo planning and execution of EHS inspections

 

Improved operational compliance overview page with new task insight metrics



Business Background
To maintain proactive compliance and mitigate risk, environmental managers and other stakeholders need an analytical dashboard to monitor compliance data. An at-a-glance view of task statuses is essential for tracking the fulfillment of various legal and internal obligations.

Key Features
The operational compliance overview page has been improved with new task insight metrics, providing a richer analytical experience. The update introduces new charts, including graphical overviews of overdue and due tasks by location and a list of upcoming tasks. These new visualizations offer immediate, actionable insights and help stakeholders better monitor and manage compliance-related activities.

 

 

Video#3: Demo Improved operational compliance overview page with new task insight metrics

 

Expansion of UK-specific incident regulatory reporting



Business Background
Businesses operating in the United Kingdom face complex regulatory reporting requirements for incidents, governed by regulations such as Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR) and the Building Safety Act (BSA). Making this process simpler and more reliable is crucial for ensuring timely and accurate compliance.

Key Features
This innovation significantly enhances regulatory reporting for the UK by expanding on RIDDOR functionalities and introducing new capabilities for BSA. The system now automatically determines the applicability of regulations and generates the necessary forms based on the incident's location. It also supports additional regulation-specific data fields to make the reporting process more robust and streamlined.

 

 

Video#4: Demo Expansion of UK-specific incident regulatory reporting



Investigation overview on the investigation object page



Business Background
Following an incident, a thorough investigation is critical for understanding the circumstances and identifying root causes. Investigation teams require a consolidated, high-level overview to effectively track the status and progress of their work, ensuring all activities are completed efficiently.

Key Features
The new investigation object page provides an intuitive and consolidated overview for the investigation team. Key features include a visual timeline of the investigation, a clear list of open and completed activities, the status of root cause analysis, and team responsibilities. This enhancement provides greater visibility and allows for more efficient management of the entire investigation process.

 

 

Video#5: Demo Investigation overview on the investigation object page





Thanks for taking the time to read this blog.

Don‚Äôt hesitate to leave a comment and check out our community page to ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. 

 

More Information

For a more in-depth exploration, please note that the EHS & Product Compliance Infodays will be held in Amsterdam from March 24th to March 25th. You can view the agenda and register here.


Ô∏èWatch the replays of our SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Early Release Series! 

From January 12 to January 16, 2026, we hosted a series of 22 expert-led live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the 2602 release of SAP Cloud ERP. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand‚Äìanywhere, anytime. 

 

Find all our assets

entry.title: Re: How to find which handling unit is related to inspection lot?
entry.content:
Pass Prueflos in QALS to get the INSP_DOC_NUMBER in S4
Pass INSP_DOC_NUMBER in QIE_INSP_DOC to get the GUID in EWM
Pass GUID = GUID_INSP_DOC in QIE_ELEMENT_IX to get the GUID in EWM
Pass GUID in QIE_ELEMENT to get the DECI_CODE_ID (Ud code, quanity) & HUFROM in EWM
Pass the HUFROM = GUID_HU in /SCWM/HUHDR to get the HUIDENT in EWM

entry.title: Understanding Your Partner Support Performance with the help of SAP for Me Reporting
entry.content:
The purpose of the Partner Support Performance report is to give transparent insight into how your partners interact with SAP Support on your behalf. It highlights key performance indicators that reflect support quality and efficiency. You can access it from SAP for Me in section Reporting or click here.

Notifications Section

The first section is a series of alerts focused on:

  • Consulting / How‚ÄëTo Share

This explains how many cases fall outside SAP Support‚Äôs scope (for example, consulting questions or how‚Äëto requests). A high percentage may indicate knowledge gaps or a need for additional enablement.

  • Proper Use of Partner S‚ÄëUser IDs

This section shows whether partners are using their own authorized S‚Äëuser IDs. Doing so ensures traceability, proper access control, and clean auditability.

  • Case Closing Behavior & Notifications

Here you see how partners handle the finalization of cases. Manual closure allows feedback and ensures the case was properly reviewed, while auto‚Äëclosure might indicate unattended items.

  • Re‚ÄëOpen Rate

This helps identify if cases were previously closed without complete resolution or lacked details. High re‚Äëopen rates can signal the need for better troubleshooting, clearer communication, or lack of attention to the case.

  • Processing Time

Processing time tracks how long partners respond or supply SAP with needed information. Faster responses usually lead to faster issue resolution.

  • Top Components & Trending Topics

This highlights components with high case volumes, helping to reveal recurring difficulties or topics where more training might be needed.

 After the alerts, the following   sections in the report give you a full, actionable picture of how partners contribute to the stability and efficiency of your SAP environment‚Äîboth cloud and on‚Äëpremise.

Summary Partner‚ÄëCreated Cases

This section shows how many cases partners create on your behalf, their resolution rates, and how many of those cases are consulting/how‚Äëto in nature providing the following benefits:

Clear visibility of partner workload
You can quickly assess how actively each partner is supporting your landscape and where they are putting their effort (cloud or on‚Äëpremise).

  • Improved partner accountability
    By seeing how many cases were resolved, reopened, or mis‚Äëclassified, you can better evaluate partner performance and maturity.
  • Ability to identify training gaps
    High consulting/how‚Äëto proportions signal areas where partners may need enablement‚Äîhelping you proactively address inefficiencies.
  • More informed resource and budgeting decisions
    Knowing which solutions generate the most partner-created cases helps prioritize investments in training, support, or tooling.

Details for Consulting/How‚ÄëTo Cases

This section breaks down the nature of consulting-oriented cases, such as configuration questions, implementation requests, user-handling issues, or coding errors:

  • Root‚Äëcause clarity
    You gain a detailed view of what is driving non‚Äësupport‚Äëscope cases‚Äîwhether they stem from configuration, user handling, or development errors. This helps focus internal or partner improvement efforts.
  • Transparency on where effort is being spent
    Understanding partner tendencies (e.g., many how‚Äëto requests vs. genuine issues) helps ensure that Support from SAP is used appropriately and efficiently.
  • Reduction of preventable cases
    When you see recurring categories‚Äîlike improper user handling‚Äîyou can address training internally or ask partners to reinforce best practices, reducing case volume over time.
  • Faster issue prevention and resolution
    With better insight into patterns, you can put corrective action in place before issues escalate or repeat.

Case Handling Practices

This section covers how cases are managed end‚Äëto‚Äëend: responsiveness, auto‚Äëclosure, reopen rates, processing times, and priority distributions. The main advantages are:

  • Shorter resolution times
    When you know where delays occur‚Äîslow partner responses, long processing time, high reopen rates‚Äîyou can drive improvements that directly reduce downtime.
  • Better collaboration and communication
    Visibility into where cases stall helps you discuss expectations with partners and establish clearer communication routines.
  • Higher case quality
    Reduced auto‚Äëclosures and lower re-open rates mean cleaner, well-documented cases that Support from SAP can resolve faster.
  • More predictable support performance
    Trends around reporter type, response behavior, and system roles help you anticipate where attention is needed and ensure smooth support operations.
  • Better control over critical issues
    Priority distribution insight ensures that urgent issues are being escalated correctly and treated with the right level of attention.

When you work with partners to manage or enhance your SAP landscape, you entrust them with handling incidents, questions, and how‚Äëto requests that keep your business running smoothly. The Partner Support Performance Report offers a clear, high-level look at how effectively your partners are supporting you, where things are going well, and where improvements might be needed.

We welcome your feedback and suggestions for further report automation and additional reports.

Please use the ‚ÄòFeedback‚Äô menu in the left edge of the page to share with us your feedback on this new tool and help us to improve the reporting functionality in SAP for Me.

Stay updated by subscribing to this blog and visiting the SAP Support Portal / Customer Insights.

SAP for Me is made for you!

Related blogs: SAP for Me goes reporting  or all related blogs to ‚ÄòCustomer Insights‚Äô reporting dashboard.

entry.title: Fiori Elements List Report: Endless Loading Spinner on Scroll with ResponsiveTable
entry.content:
Dear Community,

The List Report initially loads the first batch correctly(30 records).

  • When scrolling to the bottom (or triggering "Load More" in growing mode), a new OData request is correctly triggered and the batch request succeeds (200 OK) and returns the next 30 records in the response payload (visible in Network tab ‚Üí response ‚Üí results / value array has data).
  • However:
    • No new rows appear in the UI table.
    • The loading indicator / busy spinner shows for a few seconds then stays endlessly (never hides).
    • Table remains stuck showing only the initial 30 records.
    • No console errors (or share if any appear, e.g., binding / virtualization warnings).

The autogenerated code corresponding to this requirement is manifest.json is as follows:

"controlConfiguration": {
                "@com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.LineItem": {
                  "tableSettings": {
                    "type": "ResponsiveTable"
                  }
                }

 

What additional changes need to be made ? and changes should be done in manifest.json or do we need to add any additional annotations in the consumption view  ?

The note: https://me.sap.com/notes/0003607717 suggests the following solution, but not sure whether there is simpler solution.

  1. Use the setThreshold method in the sap.ui.table.Table class. This method allows to set the threshold to a large enough value so that instead of loading approximately 100 records, the desired amount of data is loaded.
  2. Use the FEv2 extension, onInit method to add a custom controller to the application. This custom controller can be used to get the table and set the "threshold" value.
  3. Ensure to include the custom controller in the manifest.json file.

Thank you!

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: Discovering the Power of SAP Cloud Identity Services with SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) is a central cloud identity suite on Business Technology Platform (BTP) that helps companies to easily manage users on-boarding and application services.  

It offers comprehensive single sign-on and encryption across organizational and technical boundaries, but not only this. It‚Äôs comprised of a few different components, it‚Äôs a broader application that covers more than just single sign-on into applications. 

Benefits to Using CIS 

SAP Cloud Identity Services offer several benefits for managing identities, authorizations, and Single Sign-On (SSO) across cloud and on-premise solutions. 

Key advantages include: 

  • Seamless Single Sign-On: Provides a unified SSO experience across systems using standards like SAML 2.0 and OpenID Connect, simplifying user access to multiple applications. 
  • Integration flexibility: Supports integration with both SAP and non-SAP systems, allowing for centralized user and group management. 
  • Data persistence and privacy: Provides a central repository for managing users and groups while ensuring compliance with data privacy regulations.

One of CIS's main features is the Identity Authentication Service (IAS). This feature focuses on providing secure user access to applications, and it offers a range of tools to enhance security, such as password policies, multi-factor authentication, and risk-based authentication. 

The Role of IAS 

IAS plays a crucial role in critical areas, which are: 

  1. User management:‚ÄØIAS efficiently manages user accounts and disseminates user data to various SAP cloud applications, including SAP Fieldglass. 
  2. Login management:‚ÄØEvery time users access the SAP Fieldglass URL, they are directed to the SAP IAS. This service then verifies the user‚Äôs identity either through single sign-on with the buyer‚Äôs own identity management system or by using a username and password.   
  3. Authentication: IAS facilitates the authentication process, ensuring that users are who they claim to be. This can be done through various methods such as passwords, biometrics, or tokens. 
  4. Authorization: Beyond just authenticating users, IAS also manages authorization by controlling access to resources based on user roles, attributes, and policies. This ensures that users can only access what they are permitted to. 

Pre-requisites for IAS 

In order to use IAS, you first need: 

  • A BTP license 
  • Bundles (a group of pre-configured products and services that are sold together) 
  • Tenant Provisioning (SAP Fieldglass is automatically provisioned. This speeds up the entire process to get up and running) 

Subscribing to SAP Cloud Identity Services  

If you already have the SAP Fieldglass solution, you can start using SAP Cloud Identity Services at no extra cost by subscribing to it in the SAP Business Technology Platform. 

See Identity Authentication Services (IAS) for SAP Fieldglass to learn how to subscribe to CIS and add the SAP FG application to CIS. 

Integration  

SAP is continually integrating CIS into an increasing number of its applications. This integration is crucial as SAP‚Äôs product suite evolves, ensuring centralized management of user profiles and streamlining the integration process with SAP‚Äôs offerings. You need to have CIS in order to use the following features: 

  • Embedded Analytics and Analytics Add-on 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) 
  • SAP Task Center 
  • Joule 

By integrating CIS, you gain access to Joule's intelligent automation capabilities, simplifying access to information and automating business processes, thereby enhancing productivity. 

Joule uses Identity Authentication for user login and Identity Provisioning to manage user identities and their authorizations across various business applications. 

The Identity Provisioning helps you provision identities and their authorizations to various business applications. It enables customers to set up faster and more efficient administration of user onboarding and offboarding, and its benefits are:  

  • Automatic set up of user accounts and authorizations 
  • Optimized for SAP cloud applications 
  • The reuse of existing on-premise and cloud user stores 
  • Jointly working with the SAP Identity Management product  

Start Using CIS Today! 

Do not miss all the benefits you can get using SAP CIS! It‚Äôs not just a tool for identity management, it‚Äôs a strategic asset that simplifies and enhances how you manage user profiles across your SAP cloud applications. By integrating CIS, you unlock numerous benefits, including cost-effectiveness, unified identity management, and simplified connectivity, ultimately leading to a more efficient and productive SAP environment. 

 

See Also 

What Are Cloud Identity Services 

Configuration SAP Fieldglass SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services Identity

entry.title: What‚Äôs New: SAP Integrated Product Development Update!
entry.content:
Welcome back to SAP IPD ‚Äì What‚Äôs New! In this update, we‚Äôll highlight some of the latest enhancements in SAP Integrated Product Development, including improved engineering workflows and new integration touchpoints designed to drive efficiency and collaboration.

Common Functions

Managing Teams

Administrators can search teams by user. This enhancement streamlines team management, making it easier to locate and organize teams efficiently in the Manage Teams (New) app.

Formulation

Creating a Primary Output Specification within a Recipe

Product developers can now assign a product category when creating a primary output specification directly within a recipe. This helps with search and categorization.

Using Formulation APIs 

A new API is available for Formulation that enables users to create, read, and update recipes. The Formulation API also enables the user to read calculation data.

Specification Management 

Transfer of mapped attribute property data to new SAP S/4HANA specifications

Product developers can now transfer data values from SAP Integrated Product Development property fields to the mapped properties of a newly created specification in the SAP S/4HANA system. With this we extend the seemless integration between SAP Integrated Product Development and SAP S/4HANA.

Visualization

Importing a File

The Import dialog now includes a new Script option under Import Settings, allowing you to select and run configured scripts during file imports in the Browse application. It enables customers as an example to derive data from the CAD file and use those data to enrich product data in downstream processes. Overall this enhancement supports greater automation of visualizations.

To stay informed until the next update you can: 

  • Subscribe to the What‚Äôs New Viewer on SAP Integrated Product Development Help Portal https://url.sap/5nbm4a 
  • Join our LinkedIn group SAP Solutions for PLM https://www.linkedin.com/groups/9257139/ 
  • Visit us at www.sap.com/IPD  

By the way, do you know how to provide feedback for SAP Integrated Product Development? Watch this video to find out how and send your feedback directly from the application. We always look forward to hearing from you.

entry.title: Practical SAPUI5 Form Validation: Name, Email & Password Fields
entry.content:
Introduction

Form validation plays a critical role in SAPUI5 applications. It ensures clean data entry, improves user experience, and adds an extra layer of security.

In this blog, In this article, we build a simple employee registration form that focuses on practical, real-world basic validation scenarios as follows:

  • Allow only alphabets in the Name field
  • Validate Email format as the user types
  • Block copy, cut, and paste for the Password field
  • Show clear, real-time validation feedback

If you are unfamiliar with regex, please refer to my previous article Understanding Regex in JavaScript - A Beginner-Friendly Guide for a better understanding before proceeding.

Let's discuss, along with the use case basic employee registration screen where data quality matters from the start:

  • Names should not contain numbers or special characters 
  • Email addresses must be structurally valid 
  • Passwords should be typed manually to avoid reuse or weak stored values 
  • Users should immediately know what is wrong and how to fix it

SAPUI5 provides built-in support for this through value states and event handling.

Form.view.xml
<mvc:View
  controllerName="demo.controller.Form"
  xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
  xmlns="sap.m">

  <VBox class="sapUiSmallMargin">

    <Input
      id="nameInput"
      placeholder="Full Name (Alphabets only)"
      liveChange=".onNameChange" />

    <Input
      id="emailInput"
      placeholder="Email Address"
      liveChange=".onEmailChange" />

    <Input
      id="passwordInput"
      type="Password"
      placeholder="Password (Copy/Paste Disabled)"
      paste=".onPasteBlock"
      copy=".onCopyBlock"
      cut=".onCutBlock" />

    <Button text="Submit" press=".onSubmit" />
  </VBox>
</mvc:View>

Please Note: Using liveChange allows us to validate input as the user types, rather than waiting until submission.

 

Name Validation (Alphabets Only)

Names typically contain letters and spaces. A following simple regular expression helps enforce this rule.

Form.controller.js
onNameChange: function (oEvent) {
  var sValue = oEvent.getParameter("value");
  var oInput = oEvent.getSource();

  var oRegex = /^[A-Za-z ]+$/; //Alphabets Regex

  if (!oRegex.test(sValue)) {
    oInput.setValueState("Error");
    oInput.setValueStateText("Only alphabets are allowed.");
  } else {
    oInput.setValueState("None");
  }
},

//Accepted: John, Anna Marie
//Rejected: John123, Anna!

 

Email Validation (Structural Check)

Instead of allowing any string, we validate whether the email follows a basic, widely accepted format.

Form.controller.js
onEmailChange: function (oEvent) {
  var sValue = oEvent.getParameter("value");
  var oInput = oEvent.getSource();

  var oRegex = /^[^\s@]+@[^\s@]+\.[^\s@]+$/; //Email Regex

  if (!oRegex.test(sValue)) {
    oInput.setValueState("Error");
    oInput.setValueStateText("Invalid email format.");
  } else {
    oInput.setValueState("None");
  }
},

//Valid example: test@example.com
//Invalid example: test@, name@mail

Please Note: This doesn‚Äôt verify whether the email exists, but it prevents clearly invalid entries early.

 

Password Security: Blocking Copy, Cut & Paste

For sensitive fields like passwords, allowing paste can lead to reused or insecure credentials. Here, we explicitly block copy, cut and paste actions.

Form.controller.js
onPasteBlock: function (oEvent) {
  oEvent.preventDefault();
  var oInput = oEvent.getSource();
  oInput.setValueState("Error");
  oInput.setValueStateText("Pasting is disabled for security reasons.");
},

onCopyBlock: function (oEvent) {
  oEvent.preventDefault();
},

onCutBlock: function (oEvent) {
  oEvent.preventDefault();
},

 

Final Submit Check

Before submission, we verify that no field is in an error state.

Form.controller.js
onSubmit: function () {
  var sNameInput = this.byId("nameInput");
  var sEmailInput = this.byId("emailInput");
  var sPasswordInput = this.byId("passwordInput");

  if (
    sNameInput.getValueState() === "Error" ||
    sEmailInput.getValueState() === "Error" ||
    sPasswordInput.getValueState() === "Error"
  ) {
    sap.m.MessageToast.show("Please fix the errors before submitting.");
    return;
  }

  sap.m.MessageToast.show("Form submitted successfully!");
},

This keeps the logic simple and ensures only valid data moves forward.

 

Conclusion:

With minimal code, we have achieved a clean and secure SAPUI5 form featuring:

  • Cleaner and more reliable user input
  • Immediate feedback using SAPUI5 value states
  • Better password handling for sensitive fields
  • A smoother and more professional user experience

This approach significantly improves data quality and user experience in SAPUI5 applications.

 

This is basic form validation using regex, but if you have alternative methods, improvements, or insights, please feel free to share them. I would love to learn from your experience too!

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! If you found this helpful, i would love to hear your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

I‚Äôm still new to blogging, so if you notice anything that could be improved or corrected, please don‚Äôt hesitate to let me know.

entry.title: Re: default issuing storage location in purchase requisit...
entry.content:
Options in SAP Standard

Material Master ‚Äì MRP View
In the material master (MM02 ‚Üí MRP 2 view), you can maintain a default issuing storage location. When MRP generates a purchase requisition, it will propose this storage location automatically.

MRP Areas
Define MRP Areas in customizing (SPRO ‚Üí Production ‚Üí MRP ‚Üí Planning ‚Üí Define MRP Areas). Assign specific storage locations to an MRP Area. Maintain the material master for that MRP Area with the default storage location. This way, MRP runs separately for each storage location and proposes the correct one in the requisition.

Special Procurement Key
If the requirement is always an internal stock transfer (same plant, different storage locations), you can set up a special procurement key 45 for stock transfer. Assign this key in the material master ‚Üí MRP 2 view. MRP will then generate a stock transfer requisition with both issuing and receiving storage locations.

entry.title: Custom Integration Flows for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integration with SAP IBP
entry.content:
Hello Community!

SAP has provided several standard integration flows in SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration) - such as Products, Plants and others as part of the SAP IBP - Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Package, documented here. 

However, when additional data needs to be integrated with SAP IBP, custom integration flows must be developed.

This blog walks through the process of create a simple, custom integration flow in SAP Integration suite to integrate data with SAP IBP.  As an example, it demonstrates how to integrate Work Center Header from S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to SAP Integrated Business Planning using SAP Integration Suite.

Prerequisites

  • You have activated the required business processes and set up the necessary communication arrangements in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system.
  • You have access to an SAP BTP Global Account and subaccount with an active subscription to SAP Integration Suite, including the Build Integration Scenarios capability.
  • You have preconfigured the SAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows within SAP Cloud Integration.
  • You possess a basic understanding of SAP Integration Suite and its components used to develop integration flows.
  • You have the username & password to access S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

Detailed guide regarding setting up the necessary prerequisites is documented in SAP Help Portal.

Reusable Integration Flows

As described in the prerequisites, deploy the reusable preconfigured integration package SAP IBP - Reusable Integration Flow from Discover - Integrations Section as shown below.

Configuring Security Material

Before connecting to S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, a security material needs to be created in SAP Integration Suite which will be used by the adapters to communicate. You can configure the security material using the following steps.

  • Go to Monitor ‚Üí Integrations & APIs
  • Under Manage Security, click on the Security Material tile

  • Click on Create to create a new security material. We will be configuring the username, password to connect to the S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition.
  • Select User Credentials and provide the following details.
ParameterPurpose
NameThe name with which the security material will be referenced. The value provided here will be referenced in the integration flows.
Description 
UserUsername of the instance
PasswordPassword to authenticate the user

Procedure

Identification of the necessary API

Before you can build the integration flow, the necessary API and it‚Äôs details will have to be identified.

  • Navigate to the Business Accelerator Hub.
  • Click on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as your product.
  • Click on APIs tab. Here you will see a list of packages, and APIs provided by SAP for interacting with S/4HANA Public.
  • Open the APIs tab, where you‚Äôll find a list of API packages and services provided by SAP for interacting with the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system.
  • Since our objective is to integrate Work Center Header, we will be using the corresponding ODATA V4 API, specifically the GET Work Center Header operation to retrieve all relevant entries.
    • API Reference: API Reference | Work Center | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

Creating the Integration Flow

SAP recommended naming conventions for artifacts developed using Integration Suite can be found here. They can act as a starting point to your development in SAP Integration Suite.

  • Navigate to Design ‚Üí Integrations and APIs ‚Üí Create a new Package.
  • Create a new integration flow artifact inside the package.
  • Click on Add and Open in Editor to open the GUI editor.

Building the integration flow

The integration flow is broken down into three, Local Integration Processes. They are created using Process ‚Üí Local Integration Process.

The following are the local integration processes will be built as we progress with the blog.

 

Local Integration Process NamePurpose
Transfer Data to IBPThis process is responsible to extract data from the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition API (OData) and load into IBP 
Create Batch in IBPBefore loading the actual data in IBP, a batch (data integration job) needs to be created
Post Processing in IBPThis job is responsible to trigger the IBP Post Processing (processing data from staging tables to the application tables) once the actual data load is complete.

These Local Integration Processes are then sequenced in a Main Integration Process which will trigger the subsequent process sequentially.

Transfer Data to IBP

  • Create a Local Integration Process
  • Add an External Call ‚Üí Request Reply and name it Extract Data from S/4
  • Add a Participant ‚Üí Receiver and name it S4HANA.
  • Connect the Request Reply with Receiver. Use the OData V4 adapter with the following connection configuration.
Address

<S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition URL> :443/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_work_center/srvd_a2x/sap/workcenter/0001

AuthenticationBasic
Credential NameName of the Security Material (created as part of the prerequisites)
CSRF ProtectedUncheck

  • Click on the Select button near the Resource Path. Use Remote connection source and ensure that the details are configured as per previous step.

  • Click on Step 2 button
  • Based on the API identified earlier, select the following.
OperationQuery (GET)
Select EntityWorkCenterHeader

 

Select only the necessary fields (columns) required for the integration as this will avoid unnecessary data fetch from the API.

 

Spoiler
You may also be able to filter necessary data in this step, but in this example, we are sending all the records from S/4HANA Public Cloud to IBP.

 

  • Click on the Finish button.
  • Add a new Mapping ‚Üí XSLT Mapping and connect the request reply to the XSLT mapping.
  • In your local device, create a new WorkCenterMapping.xsl file with the following code.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="3.0"
    xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">
    <xsl:output method="xml" indent="yes" encoding="UTF-8" />

    <!-- Root template -->
    <xsl:template match="/">
        <IBPWriteMasterData
            MasterDataPrefix="A01"
            FieldList="RESID,RESDESCR"
            MasterDataType="RESOURCE"
            FileName="RESOURCE"
            BatchKey="WorkCenter">
            <xsl:for-each select="WorkCenterHeader/WorkCenterHeaderType">
                <item>
                    <RESID>
                        <xsl:value-of select="WorkCenterInternalID" />
                    </RESID>
                    <RESDESCR>
                        <xsl:value-of select="WorkCenterDesc" />
                     </RESDESCR>
                </item>
            </xsl:for-each>
        </IBPWriteMasterData>
    </xsl:template>
</xsl:stylesheet>

In the above example, ensure to remember the value provided for BatchKey as this will be used in the other integration processes.

  • Upload the XSL file in the XSLT Mapping Component.
  • Add an External Call ‚Üí Request Reply and name it Write data to IBP
  • Add a Participant ‚Üí Receiver and name it as IBP_Write_Data.
  • Connect the Request Reply with the Receiver with ProcessDirect adapter and with the connection address as SAP_IBP_Write_-_Post_Data.

Finally, the local integration process should like as follows.

Creating a batch in IBP

  • Create another local integration process and name it as Create IBP Batch.
  • Add Transformation ‚Üí Content Modifier.
  • Paste the following in the Message Body of the Content Modifier.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<IBPWriteBatches>
    <IBPWriteBatch  
        Key="WorkCenter" 
        Name="Load Resource from S/4HANA Public Cloud - Integration Suite"
        Destination="<IBP System Name>"
        Command="INSERT_UPDATE"
        PlanningArea="<Planning_Area>"
        PlanningAreaVersion=""
        DetailedTrace=""
        ProcessUnchangedData="FALSE"
      />
</IBPWriteBatches>

Ensure to provide the Destination with your IBP system name and the correct planning area in the above code.

  • Add an External Call ‚Üí Request Reply and name it Create Batch in IBP
  • Add a Participant ‚Üí Receiver and name it as IBP_Create_Data.
  • Connect the Request Reply with the Receiver with ProcessDirect adapter and with the connection address as SAP_IBP_Write_-_Create_Batches.

Finally, the local integration process should like as follows.

Post Processing in IBP

  • Create another local integration process and name it as Post Processing in IBP.
  • Add Transformation ‚Üí Content Modifier.
  • Paste the following in the Message Body of the Content Modifier.
<IBPWriteBatches>
	<IBPWriteBatch 
           Command="INSERT_UPDATE"
           Destination="<IBP System Name>"
           Id="WorkCenter" 
           Index="1" 
           Key="WorkCenterInternalID" 
           Name="Load Resource from S/4HANA Public Cloud - Integration Suite" 
           PlanningArea="<Planning Area>"  
           ProcessUnchangedData="True"/>
</IBPWriteBatches>

 Provide the correct Destination and Planning Area. Also note that we have provided value of the Id attribute as WorkCenter, which is the BatchKey that we had defined earlier in our XSLT mapping. These values need to match, otherwise the data will not be loaded into IBP.

  • Add an External Call ‚Üí Request Reply and name it IBP Post Processing Call.
  • Add a Participant ‚Üí Receiver and name it as IBP_Post_Processing.
  • Connect the Request Reply with the Receiver with ProcessDirect adapter and with the connection address as SAP_IBP_Write_-_Process_Posted_Data.

The local integration process should look as follows.

Main Integration Process

Since our local integration processes are now created, we can trigger them sequentially. The Main Integration Process is already created when the integration flow was created, with the name Integration Process.

  • Remove the existing Start Message and add a timer component
  • Click on Call ‚Üí Local Call.
  • Perform this three times and sequence the components one after the other.
  • In the first local call, select the Create IBP Batch local integration process (under Processing tab)
  • In the second, select Transfer Data to IBP
  • In the third, select Post Process in IBP.

Your main integration process should look as follows.

Conclusion

The final integration flow should look as follows.

 

  • Once the integration flow is built, click on Save and then Deploy the integration flow.
  • Since we are using a timer event here, the integration flow will be executed as soon as it is deployed.
  • You can log into IBP and check the Data Integration Jobs app to see the status of the integration performed by the Integration Flow.

 

 

Using this approach, you may load any kind of data with some minor tweaks in the mappings (XSLT mapping, message body for batches and post processing).

Sources:

  • SAP Documentation on IBP Reusable Integration Flows
  • IBP Reusable Integration Flows in SAP Business Accelerator Hub

entry.title: Create an Editable ALV Grid with CRUD Functionality in ABAP
entry.content:
Objective

This program displays data from a custom table ZDB_SALES_CRUD in an editable ALV Grid. Based on user input, it allows creating new records, editing existing ones, and deleting selected entries from the table.

  1. Data Declarations

 

  • Declares the DB table from which we will retrieve and update data.

 

  • Defines a structure TY_VBAK_ALV that mirrors the structure of ZDB_SALES_CRUD. This is used for internal data handling.

 

Declares global data:

  • GT_DATA: Internal table for ALV display.
  • GS_DATA: Work area for processing one record at a time.
  • GT_FIELDCAT: ALV field catalog table.
  • GR_ALV_GRID: ALV Grid instance.
  • GV_OK_CODE: Captures user commands.

üñ•Ô∏è 2. Selection Screen

 

  • Provides a simple UI for the user to choose between display or edit mode.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è3. Program Execution Starts

 

  • Fetches data using GET_DATA and navigates to screen 100 which contains the ALV Grid.

üß© 4. Screen 100 ‚Äì Module Pool

Module: STATUS_0100 (OUTPUT)

 

  • Sets the GUI status (menu buttons like Create, Update, etc.)

 

  • Instantiates the ALV Grid object.

 

  • Builds the field catalog and populates the grid for the first time.

 

  • Makes the grid editable if user chose "Edit" mode.

 

  • Handles user interactions and maps them to specific FORM routines.

üì•5. FORM: GET_DATA

  •  

    Fetches all records from the database table into the internal table GT_DATA.

üìä6. FORM: BUILD_FIELDCATALOG

  • Dynamically builds the field catalog required by the ALV grid using a macro.

‚úèÔ∏è7. FORM: ENABLE_EDITING

  • Enables edit mode on the ALV grid.

‚ûï8. FORM: CREATE_RECORD

  •  

    Notifies the user to fill in data and save.

üîÑ9. FORM: UPDATE_RECORDS

CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->CHECK_CHANGED_DATA.SELECT * FROM ZDB_SALES_CRUD INTO TABLE LT_EXISTING.

  • Checks ALV for changes and fetches existing records from DB into a sorted table.

LOOP AT GT_DATA INTO GS_DATA.  READ TABLE LT_EXISTING ... WITH KEY VBELN POSNR.

  • Compares input data with existing DB entries based on key fields.

IF SY-SUBRC = 0.  UPDATE ZDB_SALES_CRUD FROM LS_EXISTING.ELSE.  INSERT ZDB_SALES_CRUD FROM LS_EXISTING.ENDIF.

  • Updates existing record or inserts a new one.

COMMIT WORK.REFRESH_TABLE_DISPLAY.MESSAGE 'Records updated in database.' TYPE 'S'.

  • Saves changes and refreshes the grid.

‚ùå10. FORM: DELETE_RECORDS

CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->GET_SELECTED_ROWS IMPORTING ET_INDEX_ROWS = LT_INDICES.

  • Gets user-selected rows for deletion.

LOOP AT LT_INDICES INTO LS_INDEX.  READ TABLE GT_DATA INTO GS_DATA INDEX LV_TABIX.  DELETE FROM ZDB_SALES_CRUD WHERE VBELN = ... AND POSNR = .

  • Deletes the record from the database and internal table.

COMMIT WORK.REFRESH_TABLE_DISPLAY.MESSAGE |{ LV_DELETED } record(s) deleted successfully.| TYPE 'S'.

  • Commits and informs the user of deleted rows.

CODE:

REPORT ZINSERT_SD_CUSTOM.

TABLES: ZDB_SALES_CRUD.

TYPES: BEGIN OF TY_VBAK_ALV,
         VBELN TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-VBELN,
         POSNR TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-POSNR,
         ERNAM TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-ERNAM,
         AUART TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-AUART,
         VKORG TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-VKORG,
         MATNR TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-MATNR,
         ARKTX TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-ARKTX,
         WAERK TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD-WAERK,
       END OF TY_VBAK_ALV.

DATA: GT_DATA     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF TY_VBAK_ALV,
      GS_DATA     TYPE TY_VBAK_ALV,
      GT_FIELDCAT TYPE LVC_T_FCAT,
      GS_FIELDCAT TYPE LVC_S_FCAT,
      GR_ALV_GRID TYPE REF TO CL_GUI_ALV_GRID,
      GV_OK_CODE  TYPE SY-UCOMM.


SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK B1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-002.

  PARAMETERS: P_DISP RADIOBUTTON GROUP GRP1 DEFAULT 'X',
              P_EDIT RADIOBUTTON GROUP GRP1.

SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK B1.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  PERFORM GET_DATA.
  CALL SCREEN 100.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE STATUS_0100 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'ZALV_STATUS'.
  IF GR_ALV_GRID IS INITIAL.
    CREATE OBJECT GR_ALV_GRID
      EXPORTING
        I_PARENT = CL_GUI_CONTAINER=>SCREEN0.
    PERFORM BUILD_FIELDCATALOG.
    CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->SET_TABLE_FOR_FIRST_DISPLAY
      EXPORTING
        IS_LAYOUT       = VALUE LVC_S_LAYO( EDIT = ABAP_TRUE )
      CHANGING
        IT_OUTTAB       = GT_DATA
        IT_FIELDCATALOG = GT_FIELDCAT.
    IF P_EDIT = 'X'.
      CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->SET_READY_FOR_INPUT
        EXPORTING
          I_READY_FOR_INPUT = 1.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.
ENDMODULE.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE USER_COMMAND_0100 INPUT.
  GV_OK_CODE = SY-UCOMM.
  CASE GV_OK_CODE.
    WHEN 'CREATE'.
      PERFORM CREATE_RECORD.
    WHEN 'EDIT'.
      PERFORM ENABLE_EDITING.
    WHEN 'UPDATE'.
      PERFORM UPDATE_RECORDS.
    WHEN 'DELETE'.
      PERFORM DELETE_RECORDS.
    WHEN 'BACK' OR 'EXIT' OR 'CANCEL'.
      LEAVE PROGRAM.
  ENDCASE.
ENDMODULE.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM GET_DATA.
  CLEAR GT_DATA.
  SELECT VBELN POSNR ERNAM AUART VKORG  MATNR ARKTX WAERK
    FROM ZDB_SALES_CRUD
    INTO TABLE GT_DATA.
ENDFORM.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM BUILD_FIELDCATALOG.
  CLEAR GT_FIELDCAT.
  DEFINE ADD_FIELD.
    CLEAR gs_fieldcat.
    gs_fieldcat-fieldname = &1.
    gs_fieldcat-coltext   = &2.
    APPEND gs_fieldcat TO gt_fieldcat.
  END-OF-DEFINITION.

  ADD_FIELD 'VBELN'  'Sales Document'.
  ADD_FIELD 'POSNR'  'Item No'.
  ADD_FIELD 'ERNAM'  'Created By'.
  ADD_FIELD 'AUART'  'Sales Doc Type'.
  ADD_FIELD 'VKORG'  'Sales Org'.
  ADD_FIELD 'MATNR'  'Material'.
  ADD_FIELD 'ARKTX'  'Description'.
  ADD_FIELD 'WAERK'  'Currency'.
ENDFORM.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM ENABLE_EDITING.
  CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->SET_READY_FOR_INPUT
    EXPORTING
      I_READY_FOR_INPUT = 1.
ENDFORM.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM CREATE_RECORD.
  DATA: LS_NEW TYPE TY_VBAK_ALV.
  CLEAR LS_NEW.
  APPEND LS_NEW TO GT_DATA.
  CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->REFRESH_TABLE_DISPLAY
    EXPORTING
      IS_STABLE = VALUE LVC_S_STBL( ROW = 'X' COL = 'X' ).
  CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->SET_READY_FOR_INPUT
    EXPORTING
      I_READY_FOR_INPUT = 1.
  MESSAGE 'Enter new row data and press UPDATE.' TYPE 'S'.
ENDFORM.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM UPDATE_RECORDS.
  CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->CHECK_CHANGED_DATA.
  DATA: LT_EXISTING TYPE SORTED TABLE OF ZDB_SALES_CRUD
                        WITH UNIQUE KEY VBELN POSNR,
        LS_EXISTING TYPE ZDB_SALES_CRUD.
  " Fetch all existing records
  SELECT * FROM ZDB_SALES_CRUD INTO TABLE LT_EXISTING.
  LOOP AT GT_DATA INTO GS_DATA.
    READ TABLE LT_EXISTING INTO LS_EXISTING
         WITH KEY VBELN = GS_DATA-VBELN
                  POSNR = GS_DATA-POSNR.
    IF SY-SUBRC = 0.
      " Update existing
      MOVE-CORRESPONDING GS_DATA TO LS_EXISTING.
      UPDATE ZDB_SALES_CRUD FROM LS_EXISTING.
    ELSE.
      " Insert new
      MOVE-CORRESPONDING GS_DATA TO LS_EXISTING.
      INSERT ZDB_SALES_CRUD FROM LS_EXISTING.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.
  COMMIT WORK.
  PERFORM GET_DATA.
  CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->REFRESH_TABLE_DISPLAY
    EXPORTING
      IS_STABLE = VALUE LVC_S_STBL( ROW = 'X' COL = 'X' ).
  MESSAGE 'Records updated in database.' TYPE 'S'.
ENDFORM.
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM DELETE_RECORDS.
  DATA: LT_INDICES TYPE LVC_T_ROW,
        LS_INDEX   TYPE LVC_S_ROW,
        LV_TABIX   TYPE SY-TABIX,
        LV_DELETED TYPE I VALUE 0.
  CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->GET_SELECTED_ROWS
    IMPORTING
      ET_INDEX_ROWS = LT_INDICES.
  SORT LT_INDICES BY INDEX DESCENDING.
  LOOP AT LT_INDICES INTO LS_INDEX.
    LV_TABIX = LS_INDEX-INDEX.
    READ TABLE GT_DATA INTO GS_DATA INDEX LV_TABIX.
    IF SY-SUBRC = 0.
      DELETE FROM ZDB_SALES_CRUD
        WHERE VBELN = _DATA-VBELN AND POSNR = _DATA-POSNR.
      IF SY-SUBRC = 0.
        DELETE GT_DATA INDEX LV_TABIX.
        LV_DELETED = LV_DELETED + 1.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.
  COMMIT WORK.
  CALL METHOD GR_ALV_GRID->REFRESH_TABLE_DISPLAY
    EXPORTING
      IS_STABLE = VALUE LVC_S_STBL( ROW = 'X' COL = 'X' ).
  IF LV_DELETED > 0.
    MESSAGE |{ LV_DELETED } record(s) deleted successfully.| TYPE 'S'.
  ELSE.
    MESSAGE 'No records were deleted. Please check keys.' TYPE 'I'.
  ENDIF.
ENDFORM.

entry.title: Re: New fixes and features in the Pipeline for Cloud Integration package with the Dec 2025 shipment
entry.content:
@muthukrishnanas thanks for your input, this is actually an issue of the design guidelines checks, sometimes they are too static or not flexible enough and hence end up in sort of false positives. As part of the publish process, we need to run the design guidelines checks and provide the report to the content reviewer incl our comments where the guidelines are not applicable, those comments however get lost when being published on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. In fact, the pipeline flows do comply to the design guidelines, as said where the report says it doesn't those are rather false positive. Like the one that you mention above, we do actually provide identifiers for an improved monitoring, this is also mentioned in the pipeline documentation, we fill SAP headers such as SAP_Sender, SAP_Receiver, SAP_MessageType, SAP_ApplicationID, furthermore we do support custom header properties. Another example for a false positive is wrt exception handling, we actually have defined exception subprocesses in all integration processes and local subprocesses, to reduce redundancy we defined a local subprocess for handling the exceptions which is reused in all exception subprocesses, this subprocess for sure can't have an exception subprocess otherwise it would call itself which doesn't make sense, the design guidelines however report this as non-compliant which is wrong. Another example is wrt externalized parameters. We actually use externalized parameters in the adapters as much as possible, like for the JMS queue names, for the receiver-specific JMS queue however we use an exchange property since this queue name is read from the Partner Directory, also this case is reported as non-compliant which is also wrong. We plan to feedback those flaws of the design guidelines to development, but it may be really hard to detect such situations.

Alex
